59. Nearby stands a bush full of thorns
and red Roses, with a lovely fragrance,
to which this clear liquid served as a mirror:
between high Oaks, where no sun could go;
here, hidden in the shadow within,
affords space for a cool dwelling
under branches and leaves so dense
no sun could penetrate, a gaze even less.

60. In this place, the tender plants compose
an inviting bed, which would delight anyone
coming by, tired, hot, or thirsty,
tempting them sweetly to rest.
Thus painters should never be condemned
for learning poetic works,
for they can learn and be awakened,
by many things that extend to painting.

61. At last, O happy disciples of Gyges,
whoever wanders in Pictura’s labyrinth,
urged to study its paths with diligence,
Wherever you wander, aroused to joys,
You are commanded to follow Nature’s [string]
to keep your Eyes attentively on her School.
Never let your work dishearten you.
And thus, you will enjoy a happy outcome.

right-middleAriadne gave Theseus a ball [of string] to get out of the labyrinth of Minos. Now, young Painters are instructions to follow the ball through all of nature’s workings, to arrive at a good result.

1. Young painters, who have been long locked up
And cramped with persistent labor in Art,
stiff, almost dull, you have worn out
your senses in your lust for learning to know more.
Hold on! For now, enough pulling
the plow, time to unyoke yourself from your work,
for even the strong Man needs rest.
The bow need not always be bent.

right-middleYoung painters ought to become accustomed to the Landscape, and sometimes, when there is the opportunity, to leave the city early to look at nature and amuse themselves by drawing something.

2. As soon as you see Hesperus bring from afar
the black cloak for the father of Morpheus the dreamer,
